clinical_study.brief_title: Potential Adverse Developmental and Nutritional Consequences of Helicobacter Pylori Infection in Israeli Children
clinical_study.official_title: Potential Adverse Developmental and Nutritional Consequences of Helicobacter Pylori Infection in Israeli Children

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators believe that there is an association between H. pylori infection and nutritional status and between H. pylori infection and cognitive development. The current study will examine this association in Israeli children, aged 6-12 years.

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in means of differences in height
primary_outcome.description: The means of the differences in height for age Z score between baseline and follow-up visits

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in means of differences in weight
primary_outcome.description: The means of the differences in weight for age Z score between baseline and follow-up visits

primary_outcome.measure: Changes in means of differences in body mass index
primary_outcome.description: The means of the differences in body mass index for age Z score between baseline and follow-up visits

secondary_outcome.description: The means of the differences in iron biomarkers (hemoglobin, ferritin, iron) between baseline and follow-up visits

other_outcome.description: Changes in full-Scale IQ scores and-sub-scores on WISC test between baseline and 24-months follow-up visit: will be defined as the means of the differences of these scores.

arm_group.description: Healthy children, 6-12 years old, will undergo screening for H. pylori infection by measuring anti-H. pylori and CagA IgG antibodies in the serum. The status of H. pylori infection will be confirmed using breath test (UBT). Children will be classified as i) H. pylori negative, if they test negative on UBT ii) H. pylori positive- CagA negative, if they test positive on UBT, but lack serum CagA IgG antibodies iii) H. pylori positive- CagA positive, if they are positive for H. pylori on UBT and CagA IgG antibodies.

Healthy children, 6-12 years old, will undergo screening for H. pylori infection by measuring anti-H. pylori and CagA IgG antibodies in the serum. The status of H. pylori infection will be confirmed using breath test (UBT). Children will be classified as i) H. pylori negative, if they test negative on UBT ii) H. pylori positive- CagA negative, if they test positive on UBT, but lack serum CagA IgG antibodies iii) H. pylori positive- CagA positive, if they are positive for H. pylori on UBT and CagA IgG antibodies.

biospec_descr.textblock: Blood samples will be taken for analysis and will be retained for later investigation.

study_pop.textblock: Healthy children aged 6-12 years residing in the catchment areas of primary care clinics in the Hadera sub-district of Israel.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Informed consent by parents/guardians and children
Exclusion Criteria:
- Growth retardation history
- History of prior therapy for H. pylori irradiation
- Hematological disorders
- Developmental delays
